instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2850: What is 820-2850? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Green light (doesn't seem to give an orange light), no power on.
threads.message:
Board came in not powering on 'All of a sudden'. It was filthy with dust and grime.
I gave it a clean. Gets a green light every time, but doesn't seem to give an orange light ever.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>      @ F7040       12.60
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>     @ VR5020     3.404
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>            @ <RESISTOR>R2400</RESISTOR>       5.01
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>            @ <CAPACITOR>C7252</CAPACITOR>       0
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>          @ <CAPACITOR>C7720</CAPACITOR>       3.307
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL>          @ <RESISTOR>R5704</RESISTOR>       0

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Green light (doesn't seem to give an orange light), no power on.
threads.message: Disconnect battery and try to power on with an ORIGINAL 85W charger. Also disconnect the keyboard.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Green light (doesn't seem to give an orange light), no power on.
threads.message:
Oh Crap.
I just noticed someone swapped my charger out for a knock-off.

Tracking down an original and reporting back.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Green light (doesn't seem to give an orange light), no power on.
threads.message:
Duke, you need to explain this to me please.

Retrieved my OEM charger from co-worker and BAM! We got fan spin!!

How come the OEM one works and the knock-off doesn't?


Doesn't see battery still. At least I'm half way there now.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Green light (doesn't seem to give an orange light), no power on.
threads.message:
the knockoff POS is a 60 watt charger pretending to be an 85w charger, this board needs 85w to boot up.

what is <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> measuring with the knockoff vs. the known good charger? I would usually ask this first, but duke is psychic and knew which charger you were using without asking. :)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Green light (doesn't seem to give an orange light), no power on.
threads.message:
Thanks for explaining.

Going go an measure <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> and see just how different it is. This is interesting.

:cool:

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Green light (doesn't seem to give an orange light), no power on.
threads.message:
There is a chip in the charger that contains data. The board MUST see a 85W one and will not power up with anything else. A fake charger that has the proper 85W chip in it should also work, but you never know for sure until you have a working machine to verify.
Try a known good battery and disconnect the battery indicator. If still not battery recognized probably a bad SMC/ISL
